Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Extending the Scope of Mathematical Operations used as Tools to Study Rings
Award.AbstractNarration:
A ring is a collection of elements that can be added, subtracted, or multiplied together, but not necessarily divided by one another. Rings appear in a wide range of areas within math and physics. The integers, the rational numbers, and polynomials are all commonly used examples of rings. A star operation is a useful tool for studying certain types of rings, particularly the properties of their multiplication. This project will extend the use of star operations to a larger category of rings than they are currently used for. This research will be conducted at Pohang University of Science and Technology in collaboration with Dr. Byung Gyun Kang, an expert in the field of commutative ring theory.

Star operations are a closure operation on the ideals of a commutative ring satisfying certain axioms related to principal ideals. Commonly studied star operations are the b, t, and v operations, and they are an active area of research in multiplicative ideal theory. Star operations can also be used to construct Kronecker function rings, which are invaluable for studying valuation overrings and the topology of Zariski-Riemann spaces. They are mainly studied in the context of integral domains, and comparatively little work has been done in the case of rings with zero divisors. This project will expand the use of star operations to commutative rings with zero divisors, with an emphasis on generalizing Kronecker function rings and Zariski-Riemann spaces to that setting.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Star operations are a mapping defined on the set of ideals of a commutative ring which send ideals to ideals and satisfy certain closure axioms. Any commutative ring admits at least one star operation, and there are often infinitely many for a given ring. Star operations have almost exclusively been studied in the case of integral domains, which are commutative rings without zero divisors. Work on star operations has led to the construction of numerous types of rings with interesting properties, such as Kronecker function rings, Prufer *-multiplicative domains, and pseudo-integrally closed domains. During this project, we studied star operations on commutative rings with zero divisors. Rings with zero divisors generally have unusual behavior compared to integral domain, so star operations on such rings are expected to have a much wider range of properties than they do when restricted to integral domains.

Star operations have been an important area of study in the multiplicative ideal theory of integral domains. As closure operations on ideals, star operations prove to be particularly useful in topologically motivated problems. For instance, Kronecker function rings can be built using certain star operations and are invaluable in studying the topologies of Zariski-Riemann spaces. However, relatively little work has been done on star operations beyond the integral domain setting, such as in commutative rings with zero divisors. This project generalized the Kronecker function ring construction to the setting of rings with zero divisors, as well as establishing a basic theory of Kronecker function rings using power series rather than polynomials.

This project also provided an international research experience; gave exposure to Korean language, society, and culture; and connected members of the international scientific community that will hopefully lead to future collaborations. These results will also be presented in seminars to help spread mathematical knowledge to interested members of the academic community. In addition to greatly expanding the utility of star operations within multiplicative ideal theory, these results are likely to be applicable to the study of spectral spaces and the broader field of algebraic geometry. These are highly active fields of mathematics, and star operations on rings with zero divisors could give researchers a powerful new tool to work with.
